header.title: Let's end ageism | Ashton Applewhite
header.subtitle: NA
header.postText: It's not the passage of time that makes it so hard to get older. It's ageism, a prejudice that pits us against our future selves -- and each other. Ashton Applewhite urges us to dismantle the dread and mobilize against the last socially acceptable prejudice. 'Aging is not a problem to be fixed or a disease to be cured,' she says. 'It is a natural, powerful, lifelong process that unites us all.'. . Check out more TED talks: http://www.ted.com. . The TED Talks channel features the best talks and performances from the TED Conference, where the world's leading thinkers and doers give the talk of their lives in 18 minutes (or less). Look for talks on Technology, Entertainment and Design -- plus science, business, global issues, the arts and more.. . Follow TED on Twitter: http://www.twitter.com/TEDTalks. Like TED on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/TED. . Subscribe to our channel: https://www.youtube.com/TED

Ms. Applewhite reminds me of a sociology professor I had last semester.  Great TED Talk!

She makes a few honest observations, then twists them into arguments for counterculture. 
 She never differentiates between the fundamentals of corporate capitalism and competitive capitalism. She just alludes to the conclusion that capitalism is inherently evil. She all but openly states that human competition is a thing that should not be. 
 Western competitive capitalism is what built the western world and has allowed us to reach this point where we can question everything, rather than be tied to spending every waking hour working for survival. Competition is the fuel of any free society. Without competition there would be no great inventors, no great athletes or artists. Humans didn't invent competition, nature did. When we compete we are only doing what we were born to do. This is why a freemarket based society thrives more than any kind of cooperation based models. Cooperation based societies caused over 100,000,000 deaths in the 20th century. 
 We only have corporate capitalism because of cooperative minded policies. Corporate/bank bailouts, government strong arming through taxation to invest in the stock market, subsidy programs. Public welfare programs such as, social security, welfare, food stamps, socialized healthcare, planned parenthood, wic, public schools,  medicare/medicade, etc, etc... are all socialism. I'm not saying they are good or bad, only pointing out that if you're going to blame our problems on capitalism then at least realize we do not live in a capitalist system and haven't for almost a hundred years. Since these programs first started being implemented inflation has risen over 2300%. 
 The first thing socialism requires is fiat currency because no country has enough gold in its reserves to pay for providing for all of its citizens needs. For a fiat system to "work" it's society must adopt a Keynesian economic model since it's currency is no longer a carrier of value, but only a placeholder of value. Real value is tangible and solid. Fiat is representative of an idea. 
 All great empires and nations fell ultimately to inflation. Rome was only succesfully invaded when they could no longer afford to pay an army. In the end their currency was so worthless they wouldn't even accept it from their own citizens to pay their taxes and demanded to be paid in gold.
 This speaker appears to make sense on the surface but she is really prescribing how to kill freedom and prosperity.

Its not a social construct, and its not just a market that these so called big pharmaceutical companies have pushed on people. It's science. As peop le age, the telomeres that act as a cap for the end of a chromosome begin to shorten with each replication as a person ages, causing each new cell to be more damaged than the last. Now Im not going to try and tell you that the nullment of her argument makes it ok to dehuman ize old people, but frankly, I dont think that happens too much anyway.
